Award.AwardTitle: Beyond elastic rebound: extracting permanent strain from interseismic deformation
Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the main uses of GPS data in studying the boundaries of tectonic plates is to understand current rates for fault movements and understand how faults interact. This kind of understanding can all feed into a better assessment of earthquake hazards because it helps us better understand the longer term behavior of fault systems. The researchers in the project will try to reconcile two kinds of models, those that characterize single faults with those that look at long-term evolution of a full plate boundary. The results of this work have important implications for how fast plate boundaries are moving and how the ground around faults deforms over time. The work will use two examples, on in Taiwan, and the other in Southern California. Comparing and contrasting the two areas will improve overall understanding of earthquakes processes.

The purpose of the proposed research is to develop dynamic models of geodetic data that extend traditional elastic models to include permanent deformation. The approach is to develop viscoelastic-plastic boundary element models in which the deforming crust is loaded by far-field stresses and faults slip and the surrounding crust deforms in response to the loads. They will employ geodetic data, stress state inferred from focal mechanism data, and geologic and thermochronologic data to constrain the deformation models. In Taiwan they will use the GPS-derived horizontal and vertical velocity fields, an island-wide leveling network, and stress orientations throughout the crust to address several key outstanding issues about the fault architecture responsible for mountain building processes in Taiwan. They will test several models of deep fault geometry and a proposed deep-seated underplating process
for uplifting the core of the mountain range. Model results will be compared with low-temperature thermochronology. In southern California the research will examine models of long-term deformation across the strike-slip fault system to determine the relative contributions of various pate-driving forces (plate boundary forces, gravitational potential energy, mantle drag) and compare predicted long-term fault slip rates with geologic slip rate estimates. They will focus on the important outstanding problem of the portion of deformation that occurs as off-fault inelastic yielding distribution through the crust versus deformation that is accommodated by slip on faults.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A principal goal of monitoring surface motions in plate boundary settings with GPS measurements is inferring the potential for earthquakes. GPS measurments of ground distortions (strain) can be used to infer how much strain is accumulating in Earth's crust between earthquakes, which indicates how much stress is accumulating elastically on faults and is available for release in future earthquakes. A significant challenge in doing this is determining how much of the measured strain is elastic and recoverable in future earthquakes, and how much is permanent strain that does not get released in future earthquakes. 

The objective of this study was to develop models in Taiwan and California, where we have dense measurements of strain at the surface of the Earth, that are cabable of helping us decifer how much strain is permanent or recoverable. We developed numerical models of these two regions that explicitly incorporate both elastic and non-elastic deformation. 

In Taiwan we found that spatial gradients in horizontal velocities of the ground surface (horizontal strain) is almost entirely elastic and recoverable, meaning horizontal velocities can be used to infer earhtquake potential. On the other hand, the vertical motions measured in Taiwan contain a large component of deformation that is permanent. That is, a large portion of present-day vertical motions in Taiwan are reflect the long-term (10 to 100 thousand years) mountain building processes and the contribution from elastic, recoverable motions attributed with accumulated stresses on faults is relatively minor.

In southern California we have layed the groundwork for future models of the entire fault system that incorporate elastic, recoverable strain and permanent, non-recoverable strain. These models will allow us in the future to better infer the earthquake potential using GPS data. To lay this groundwork, we have learned how to set up numerical simulations of faults embedded in an elasto-plastic crust. Future simulations will us this this model to computer the rate of motions on California faults and the portion of strain occuring off of major faults and compare simulation results with GPS measurements.
